text:
Hi All, I have a question about analysing bets placed by my strategy I'd appreciate a sense check on. My strategy places only lay bets, so I say that value is
```value = bsp - price taken```
I sum 'value' for all the bets my strategy places over a period as a quick and easy yes/no for is value being taken - if the total value is positive I say that I have taken value, and if it's negative I say I haven't. I would appreciate anybody's thoughts on whether this is an acceptable way to roughly determine whether my strategy takes value before further assessment of the bets. Cheers

elements.text: Hi All, I have a question about analysing bets placed by my strategy I'd appreciate a sense check on. My strategy places only lay bets, so I say that value is
value = bsp - price taken

I sum 'value' for all the bets my strategy places over a period as a quick and easy yes/no for is value being taken - if the total value is positive I say that I have taken value, and if it's negative I say I haven't. I would appreciate anybody's thoughts on whether this is an acceptable way to roughly determine whether my strategy takes value before further assessment of the bets. Cheers

text: I don't know if this is best but I take 1 - (price/BSP) for lay bets to get a percentage vs BSP

elements.text: I don't know if this is best but I take 1 - (price/BSP) for lay bets to get a percentage vs BSP

text: That's interesting - I'll give that a go, cheers

text: It's the same as "cashing out" at BSP so assuming BSP is 0EV then theoretically you'd be calculating your EROI. Although to be honest I'm not 100% confident this is correct.

elements.text: It's the same as "cashing out" at BSP so assuming BSP is 0EV then theoretically you'd be calculating your EROI. Although to be honest I'm not 100% confident this is correct.

text:
amateur question here, once I start streaming the raw data from betfair, is there an easy way to get it into a dataframe including the usual fields you'd expect, market_book.market_id,
        market_book.inplay,
        market_book.status,
        market_book.total_matched,
        runner.selection_id,
        runner.status,
        runner.last_price_traded,
        runner.total_matched,
        runner.ex.available_to_back[0].price,
        runner.ex.available_to_back[0].size,using flumine?

text: I just edited my answer because in my formula p should be 1 - 1 / BSP not 1 / BSP. My formula is the same as 1 - price / BSP

elements.text: I just edited my answer because in my formula p should be 1 - 1 / BSP not 1 / BSP. My formula is the same as 1 - price / BSP

text:
But to explain why I use that form:

For any bet, regardless of backing or laying, the EROI is
```probability bet wins * return if bet wins + probability bet loses * return if bet loses```
For this situation, as I've already said the probability the bet wins is 1 - 1 / BSP. Always the probability the bet loses is 1 - probability the bet wins. The return if the bet wins is 1, the return if the bet loses is -(price - 1)

For a back bet, the probability the bet wins would be 1 / BSP, (in this situation where we are assuming BSP is the true price) the return if it wins would be (price - 1) and the return if it loses would be -1

elements.text:
But to explain why I use that form:

For any bet, regardless of backing or laying, the EROI is
probability bet wins * return if bet wins + probability bet loses * return if bet loses

For this situation, as I've already said the probability the bet wins is 1 - 1 / BSP. Always the probability the bet loses is 1 - probability the bet wins. The return if the bet wins is 1, the return if the bet loses is -(price - 1)

For a back bet, the probability the bet wins would be 1 / BSP, (in this situation where we are assuming BSP is the true price) the return if it wins would be (price - 1) and the return if it loses would be -1

text: Guys, can any of you confirm whether this is "expected": if I go on a an event on the website of the exchange and hit the "update" button reasonably often (say, every couple of seconds) you see the odds change. Now, if you open the requests your browser does (the bymarket...) ones, and look at the 'lastMatchedTime' of the market, you will notice that it goes back and forth in time between updates...

elements.text: Guys, can any of you confirm whether this is "expected": if I go on a an event on the website of the exchange and hit the "update" button reasonably often (say, every couple of seconds) you see the odds change. Now, if you open the requests your browser does (the bymarket...) ones, and look at the 'lastMatchedTime' of the market, you will notice that it goes back and forth in time between updates...
